page.title: 04Beswick Hall
page.content: "Beswick" appears to come from "Besi" and "wic", meaning "Besi's dairy farm". Two of the major farming families of the area occupy the Hall - the Beachell family in the south wing and the Duggleby family in the north. The Hall was built around 1590, and is mainly of red brick with black brick diapering. There are three storeys plus attics. The roof is tiled with stone dressing at the gable ends. Some of the former bar and transome windows are now blocked, possibly as a result of adaptations and alterations carried out in the 18th Century. The southern wing is approached by a central front gravelled drive, leading to a front-facing (east) door. A second drive leads to the northern wing and its separate, north-facing doorway. The Hall stands in its own walled grounds and gardens.
